required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Noninvasive Biomarkers for Monitoring Cardiometabolic Risk in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Noninvasive Biomarkers for Monitoring Cardiometabolic Risk in Children

lead_sponsor.agency: West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine

clinical_study.source: West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to identify salivary biomarkers for monitoring cardiometabolic risk in children. The study hypothesis is that a combination of salivary biomarkers will predict the presence of risk factors including impaired fasting glucose, hypertension and dyslipidemia and will reflect changes in these risk factors over time.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation (R values) of salivary biomarkers with blood pressure percentile and serum glucose, HDL, total cholesterol, triglyceride and insulin levels in children
Predictive utility (C-statistic) of salivary biomarkers for development of metabolic syndrome during childhood and adolescence
primary_outcome.time_frame: final assessment at age 18 (up to 14 years depending on age of enrollment)

study_pop.textblock: Children participating in the CARDIAC Boot Camp program at the Robert C. Byrd Clinic in Lewisburg WV

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participating in the CARDIAC Boot Camp Program
- Between the ages of 4 and 17
- Parental permission
- Ability to provide assent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to comply with saliva collection procedures
- Renal insufficiency or juvenile gout

overall_official.affiliation: West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine

overall_official.last_name: Jill Cochran, PhD, MSN, RN-C FNP
overall_official.affiliation: West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine

facility.name: West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine
